title: 106_s120
content: The "Agricultural Trade Reform Act of 1999" is the short title of this Act. It defines the term "domestic industry" among other things. The "Agricultural Trade Reform Act of 1999" defines "domestic industry" as the producers of like or directly competitive articles or perishable agricultural products in a specific geographic area of the United States. The "Agricultural Trade Reform Act of 1999" defines "domestic industry" as producers of like or directly competitive perishable agricultural products in specific US geographic areas. The Act also allows the Commission to consider domestic producers of perishable agricultural, citrus, or potato products in a specific area if their production constitutes a significant portion of total domestic production. The "Agricultural Trade Reform Act of 1999" defines "domestic industry" as producers of like or directly competitive perishable agricultural products in specific US geographic areas. The Act also allows the Commission to consider domestic producers of perishable agricultural, citrus, or potato products in a specific area if their production constitutes a significant portion of total domestic production. The term 'specific geographic area of the United States' is defined as a distinguishable geographic area where perishable agricultural, citrus, or potato products are produced. The term 'significant portion of the domestic industry in the United States' refers to an important part of the industry characterized by production in the same growing season. SEC. 3. PROVISIONAL RELIEF. Section 202(d)(1)(C) of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to allow for provisional relief in cases of injury from imports of perishable agricultural, citrus, or potato products that have been monitored for at least 90 days. Requests for relief can be made by petition or by the President, Trade Representative, or relevant committees. The Trade Act of 1974 allows for provisional relief in cases of injury from imports of perishable agricultural, citrus, or potato products. The Commission must make a determination within 21 days of the request to prevent serious injury to the domestic industry. The Trade Act of 1974 allows for provisional relief in cases of injury from imports of perishable agricultural products. The Commission may waive the 90-day monitoring requirement in certain cases. The Trade Act of 1974 allows for provisional relief in cases of injury from imports of perishable agricultural products. The Commission may waive the 90-day monitoring requirement in certain cases. Section 202(a)(2)(B)(i) of the Act is amended to include specific subsection references. Section 2252(a)(2)(B)(i) is amended to include specific subsection references. Section 202(d)(1)(A) is amended to include potato products. Section 202(d)(5) is amended to define potato products.
